column1:
Jack and his friends were playing golf one Saturday. As they are getting ready
to tee off
column2:
a guy walks up and asks if he can join them. The friends look at
each other
column3: look at the guy and say
column4: ''Sure.'' About two holes into the game
column5:
the
friends get curious about what the guy does for a living. So they ask him. The
stranger tells them he''s a hitman. They all laugh. The guy says
column6: ''No really
column7:
I
am a hitman. My gun is in my golf bag. I carry it everywhere. You can take a
look at it if you like.'' So Jack decides to check it out. He opens the bag and
column8: sure enough
column9:
there is a rifle with a huge scope attached. Jack gets all excited
and says
column10:
''WOW! I bet I can see my house through here! May I look?'' The hit man
replies
column11: ''Sure.'' So Jack looks and says
column12:
''YEAH! You can see my house! I can even
see through the windows into my bedroom. There''s my wife. Wait
column13:
there''s my next
door neighbor! And he''s naked too!'' This really upsets Jack so he asks how much
it would be for a hit. The hitman replies
column14:
''I get $1000 every time I pull the
trigger.'' Jack responds
column16: OK
column17:
I want two hits. I want you to shoot
my wife right in the mouth. She''s always nagging at me and I can''t stand it.
Second
column18: I want you to shoot my neighbor in the penis
column19:
just for screwing around
with my wife.'' The hit man agrees
column20:
gears up and looks through the scope. He''s
looking for about five minutes until finally Jack starts to get really impatient
and asks
column21: ''What are you waiting for? The hitman replies
column22:
''Relax..... I''m about
to save you a thousand bucks!''

column1:
A young blonde was on vacation in the depths of Louisiana.
She wanted a pair of genuine alligator shoes in the worst way
column2:
but was very
reluctant to pay the high prices the local vendors were asking.

\n

After becoming very frustrated with the "no haggle" attitude of one of the
shopkeepers
column3: the blonde shouted
column4:
"Maybe I''ll just go out and catch my own
alligator so I can get a pair of shoes at a reasonable price!"

\n

The shopkeeper said
column5: "By all means
column6:
is my guest. Maybe
You�酶惟ll luck out and catch yourself a big one!"

\n

Determined
column7: the blonde turned and headed for the swamps
column8:
set on catching
herself an alligator.

\n

Later in the day
column9: the shopkeeper is driving home
column10:
when he spots the young
woman standing waist deep in the water
column11: shotgun in hand. Just then
column12:
he sees a
huge 9 foot alligator swimming quickly toward her. She takes aim
column13:
kills the
creature and with a great deal of effort hauls it on to the swamp bank. Laying
nearby were several more of the dead creatures.

\n

The shopkeeper watches in amazement. Just then the blonde flips the alligator
on it''s back
column14: and frustrated
column15: shouts out
column16: "Damn it
column17:
this
One isn''t wearing any shoes either!"

column1:
The following appeared in a computer magazine in Mr. Dvorak''s column (according with the original sender)

\n

Dear Mr. Dvorak:

\n

Ann Landers wouldn''t print this. I have nowhere else to turn. I have to get the word out. Warn other parents. I must be rambling on. Let me try and explain. It''s about my son
column2: Billy. He''s always been a good
column3: normal ten year old boy. Well
column4: last spring we sat down after dinner to select a summer camp for Billy. We sorted through the camp brochures. There were the usual camps with swimming
column5: canoeing
column6: games
column7: singing by the campfire you know. There were sports camps and specialty camps for weight reduction
column8: music
column9: military camps and camps that specialized in Tibetan knot tying. I tried to talk him into Camp Winnepoopoo. It''s where he went last year. (He made an adorable picture out of painted pinto beans and macaroni). Billy would have none of it. Billy pulled a brochure out of his pocket. It was for a COMPUTER CAMP. We should have put our foot down right there
column10:
if only we had known. He left three weeks ago. I don''t know what''s happened. He''s changed. I can''t explain it. See for yourself. These are some of my little Billy''s letters.

\n

Dear Mom
column11:
\n

The kids are dorky nerds. The food stinks. The computers are the only good part. We''re learning how to program. Late at night is the best time to program
column12:
so they let us stay up.

\n

Love
column13:
\n

Billy.

\n

Dear Mom
column14:
\n

Camp is O.K. Last night we had pizza in the middle of the night. We all get to choose what we want to drink. I drink Classic Coke. By the way
column15: can you make Szechwan food? I''m getting used to it now. Gotta go
column16:
it''s time for the flowchart class.

\n

Love
column17:
\n

Billy.

\n

P.S. This is written on a word processor. Pretty swell
column18:
huh? It''s spell checked too.

\n

Dear Mom
column19:
\n

Don''t worry. We do regular camp stuff. We told ghost stories by the glow of the green computer screens. It was real neat. I don''t have much of a tan ''cause we don''t go outside very often. You can''t see the computer screen in the sunlight anyway. That wimp camp I went to last year fed us weird food too. Lay off
column20: Mom. I''m okay
column21:
really.

\n

Love
column22:
\n

Billy.

\n

Dear Mom
column23:
\n

I''m fine. I''m sleeping enough. I''m eating enough. This is the best camp ever. We scared the counselor with some phony worm code. It was real funny. He got mad and yelled. Frederick says it''s okay. Can you send more money? I spent mine on a pocket protector and a box of blank diskettes. I''ve got to chip in on the phone bill. Did you know that you can talk to people on a computer? Give my regards to Dad.

\n

Love
column24:
\n

Billy.

\n

Dear Mother
column25:
\n

Forget the money for the telephone. We''ve got a way to not pay. Sorry I haven''t written. I''ve been learning a lot. I''m real good at getting onto any computer in the country. It''s really easy! I got into the university''s in less than fifteen minutes. Frederick did it in five
column26: he''s going to show me how. Frederick is my bunk partner. He''s really smart. He says that I shouldn''t call myself Billy anymore. So
column27:
I''m not.

\n

Signed
column28:
\n

William.

\n

Dear Mother
column29:
\n

How nice of you to come up on Parents Day. Why''d you get so upset? I haven''t gained that much weight. The glasses aren''t real. Everybody wears them. I was trying to fit in. Believe me
column30: the tape on them is cool. I thought that you''d be proud of my program. After all
column31: I''ve made some money on it. A publisher is sending a check for $30
column32: 000. Anyway
column33:
I''ve paid for the next six weeks of camp. I won''t be home until late August.

\n

Regards
column34:
\n

William.

\n

Mother
column35:
\n

Stop treating me like a child. True -- physically I am only ten years old. It was silly of you to try to kidnap me. Do not try again. Remember
column36: I can make your life miserable (i.e. - the bank
column37: credit bureau
column38:
and government computers). I am not kidding. O.K.? I won''t write again and this is your only warning. The emotions of this interpersonal communication drain me.

\n

Sincerely
column39:
\n

William.

\n

See what I mean? It''s been two weeks since I''ve heard from my little boy. What can I do
column40: Mr. Dvorak? I know that it''s probably too late to save my little Billy. But
column41: if by printing these letters you can save JUST ONE ...CHILD from a life of programming
column42: please
column43:
I beg of you to do so.

\n

Thank you very much.

\n

Sally Gates
column44:
\n

Concerned Parent

column1:
Q: Why didn''t the monster make the football team?
A: Because he threw like a ghoul!
THE TWELVE DAYS OF CHRISTMASOn the first day of Christmas
column2: my kitten ruined for me........    A batch of my special hand-print cookies. I had turned my back to grab the cookie sheet sitting on the stove. In that micro-second
column3: Sara climbed onto the table
column4: poked her paw into the delightfully kneady mixture and
column5: suddenly off-balance
column6: fell into the cookie dough. Net loss? Six cups of flour
column7: four cups of sugar
column8: three sticks of butter.... Of course
column9: it would have been cheaper to remove the feline ingredient
column10: pick out the hairs
column11: and just rename the recipe Paw Print Cookies. On the second day of Christmas
column12: my kitten accompanied me........    On a trip to the vet clinic. Who knew that skinny curling ribbon has feline taste appeal? I didn''t. Damages: $28 for the office visit
column13: $36 for anesthesia so the veterinarian could take $55 X-rays in case Sara had taste-tested any other Christmas decorations
column14: and a heck of a lot of embarrassment when the vet removed the 3'' curly tail in slightly less than two seconds by tugging at it with a pair of tweezers. On the third day of Christmas
column15: my kitten wrecked for me........    13 ornaments on my Christmas tree. My mistake was forgetting to chain the decorations to the branches. My other error was leaving the room to go to the bathroom while Sara feigned sleeping under the tree. How was I to know the was actually measuring its climbing potential? Value of broken bulbs? 7.50 plus tax.    On the fourth day of Christmas
column16: my kitten broke for me........    A statue in my Lenox Nativity. Would you believe two Wise men plus a head? Lenox nativity figurines: $55.99    On the fifth day of Christmas
column17: my kitten scratched for me........    The kid across the street who collects for charity. It was an accident. She merely wanted to reach out and touch someone. Unfortunately
column18: she used a unsheathed claw to do so. I settled out-of-court for the cost of a jacket to replace the boy''s blood stained one and a hefty donation to the charity of their choice. Although the amount must remain secret according to our settlement
column19: let me put it this way. You haven''t seen many soldiers for the Salvation Army this year
column20: have you? Think: Major Windfall!    On the sixth day of Christmas
column21: my kitten opened for me........    The presents beneath my Christmas tree. It was only two
column22: really. While doing some early shopping at a discount store
column23: I purchased a catnip mouse for Sara''s stocking. Apparently
column24: anything in the same bag as catnip takes on its potent aroma for a very long time. Replacement costs: $3.99 for another roll of Christmas wrapping paper
column25: $4.50 for two empty boxes
column26: $1 each for the kind of bows Sara can''t unravel.    On the seventh day of Christmas
column27: my kitten lost for me........    The earrings I bought for my sister Mary. Actually
column28: it was one earring but since Mary doesn''t have a hole in her nose or navel
column29: a pair of matching earrings does make a more appealing gift. Sale price: $29.95 plus tax.    On the eighth day of Christmas
column30: my kitten helped me........    Replace my E and G guitar strings. Would you believe a kitten could fit into the itty-bitty hole in the middle of my Yamaha guitar? Neither could I
column31: but Sara thought so. And she succeeded once she got those rascally strings out of the way. Unfortunately
column32: her little rear end couldn''t get out the way I came in. After paying through the whiskers for her previous escapades
column33: I would have been willing to leave her in the guitar for the duration of the holiday season
column34: except that she chose to get stuck two hours before I was due at the nursing home for our annual Christmas carol sing-a-long. Set of steel guitar strings: $12.95; jar of petroleum jelly: 79 cents.    On the ninth day of Christmas
column35: my kitten destroyed for me........    My Christmas card list when she walked across my computer''s delete key. Cost for call to Computer Country''s 900/help line: $17.50. And I still don''t know what happened to the listings of B through H.    On the tenth day of Christmas
column36: my kitten hid from me........    The remote control from my 13-inch TV. This wouldn''t be such a disaster if she hadn''t previously stolen the power knob. I missed a week''s worth of Christmas specials
column37: including my all-time favorite
column38: ''It''s a Wonderful Life.'' Rental of ''It''s a Wonderful Life'': $2; purchase of book
column39: ''Good owners
column40: great cats'': $24.95. Unfortunately
column41: it never mentions the psychological profile of kittens with kleptomania.    On the eleventh day of Christmas
column42: my kitten ate for me........    The drumsticks off my 19-pound turkey. OK
column43: OK
column44: So this one time it was my fault. I knew I never should have uttered those now infamous words: ''Your first turkey
column45: Sara. Want to try just a little piece?'' Cost: Christmas Dinner.       On the 12th day of Christmas........    Sara rested. And so
column46: thank goodness
column47: did my VISA card.

column1:
Three Texas plastic surgeons were playing golf together and discussing surgeries they had performed.

\n

One of them said
column2: "I''m the best plastic surgeon in Texas. A concert pianist lost 7 fingers in an accident
column3: I reattached them
column4:
and 8 months later he performed a private concert for the Queen of England."

\n

One of the others said. "That''s nothing. A young man lost both arms and legs in an accident
column5: I reattached them
column6:
and 2 years later he won a gold medal in 5 field events in the Olympics."

\n

The third surgeon said
column7: "You guys are amateurs. Several years ago a cowboy who was high on cocaine and alcohol rode a horse head-on into a train traveling 80 miles an hour. All I had left to work with was the horse''s ass and a cowboy hat. Now he''s president of the United States."

column1: After Christmas break
column2:
the teacher asked her small pupils how they spent their holidays.

\n

One small boy''s reply went like this:

\n

We always spent Christmas with Grandpa and Grandma. They used to live here in a big brick house
column3:
but Grandpa got retarted and they moved to Arizona.

\n

They go to a big building they call a wrecked hall. But if it was wrecked
column4: it is fixed now. They play games there and do exercises
column5:
but they don''t do them very well.

\n

There is a swimming pool and they go to it and just stand in the water with their hats on. I guess they don''t know how to swim. My Grandma used to bake cookies and stuff
column6:
but I guess she forgot how. Nobody cooks there. They all go to fastfood restaurants.

\n

As you come into the park
column7:
there is a doll house with a man sitting in it. He watches all day so they can''t get out without him seeing them. They wear badges with their names on them. I guess they don''t know who they are.

\n

My Grandma said Grandpa worked hard all his life and earned his retardment. I wish they would move back home
column8: but I guess the man in the doll house won''t let them out.

column1:
A lady in her late 40''s goes to a plastic surgeon for a facelift.

\n

The doctor tells her of a new procedure called ''The Knob''.

\n

A small knob is implanted on the back of a woman�酶惟s head and it can be turned to tighten the skin
column2:
producing the effect of a brand new facelift forever.

\n

Naturally
column3:
the woman wants ''The Knob''.

\n

Fifteen years later
column4: she goes back to the surgeon. "All these years
column5:
everything�酶惟s been fine. I�酶惟ve turned ''The Knob'' on lots of occasions and I�酶惟ve loved the results. But now I�酶惟ve developed two problems.

She did that and he started on the tattoo (the joke goes great if you do all the tattoo-type noises etc.).

\n

Pretty soon he''s done
column4:
blows off the dust and admired his work. "Who the fuck''s that?" she says.

"It''s Paul McCartney he says".

"Doesn''t look like hime at all" says she.

"Now get it right or I''ll report you".

So the tattooist starts on the othert thigh. Really trying hard to do a better job. (Noises again go great when telling the joke). Finally he''s done
column5:
blows off the dust and feels pretty good. The woman is pissed off "No fucking way that''s Paul Mccartney" she says.

"It bloody well is" says the man.

"Listen I''ll get a second opinion" He goes out of his store and grabs the first person he sees.

The guy is a drunk who''s been stumbling along the sidewalk. The tattoist drags the drunk into his store. There''s the woman
column6:
sitting legs apart with nothing on below her waist. The tattoist says to the drunk (pointing at the womans legs) "Tell me who the hell you think that is"

\n

The drunk says (in a drunken slur voice) "I''ve no idea who the people are on her thighs but the guy in the middle is a dead ringer for Willie Nelson".

column1: A friend just got back from a holiday ski trip to Utah with the kind of story that warms the cockles of anybody''s heart. Conditions were perfect
column2: 12 below
column3: no feeling in the toes
column4:
basic numbness all over. The "Tell me when we''re having fun" kind of day.

\n

One of the women in the group complained to her husband that she was in dire need of a restroom. He told her not to worry
column5: that he was sure there was relief at the top of the lift in the form of a powder room for female skiers in distress. He was wrong
column6: of course
column7:
and the pain did not go away.

\n

If you''ve ever had nature hit its panic button in you
column8: then you know That a temperature of 12 below zero doesn''t help matters. So with time running out
column9:
she weighed her options.

\n

Her husband
column10: picking up on the intensity of the pain
column11: suggested that since she was wearing an all white ski outfit
column12: she should go off in the woods. No one would ever notice
column13: he assured her. The white will provide more than adequate camouflage. So she headed for the tree line
column14: began disrobing and proceeded to do her thing. If you''ve ever parked on the side of a slope
column15: then you know there is a right way and a wrong way to set your skies so you don''t move. Yup
column16:
you got it. She had the skies positioned the wrong way.

\n

Steep slopes are not forgiving
column17: even during embarrassing moments. Without any warning
column18: the woman found herself skiing backward
column19: out of control racing through the trees
column20: somehow missing all of them
column21: and on to the slope. Her derriere and the reverse side were still bare
column22: her pants down around her knees
column23: and she was picking up speed all the while she continued on backwards
column24: totally out-of-control
column25:
creating an unusual sight for the other skiers.

\n

The woman skied
column26: if you define that verb loosely
column27: back under the lift
column28: and finally collided violently with a pylon. The bad news was she broke her arm and was unable to pull up the ski pants. At long last her husband arrived
column29: put an end to her nude show
column30: then went to the base of the mountain and summoned the ski patrol
column31:
who transported her to a hospital.

\n

In the emergency room she was regrouping when a man with a broken leg was put in a bed next to hers.

\n

"So
column32: how''d you break your leg?" She asked
column33:
making small talk.

\n

"It was the darndest thing you ever saw
column34:
he said I was riding up this ski lift and suddenly I couldn''t believe my eyes. There was this crazy woman skiing backwards out of control down the mountain with her bare bottom hanging out. I leaned over to get a better look and I guess I didn''t realize how far I''d moved. I fell out of the lift."

\n

"So how''d you break your arm?"

column1: After a very successful career
column2:
a former Human Relations guru found herself at
the pearly gates.

\n

"Welcome to Heaven
column3: said St.Peter. Before you get settled in though
column4:
it
seems we have a problem. You see
column5: strangely enough
column6:
we''ve never once had a Human
Resources Director make it this far
column7:
and we''re not really sure what to do with
you
column8:
so what we''re going to do is let you have a day in Hell and a day in Heaven
and then you can choose whichever one you want to spend an eternity in."

\n

With that St. Peter put the executive in an elevator and went down to hell.
The doors opened
column9:
and she found herself stepping out onto the putting green of a
beautiful golf course. In the distance was a country club
column10:
and standing in front
of her were all her friends - fellow executives that she had worked with - and
they were all dressed in evening gowns and cheering for her. They ran up
column11:
kissed
her and talked about old times.

\n

They played an excellent round of golf
column12: and at night went to the country club
column13: where she enjoyed an excellent steak and lobster dinner. She met the Devil
column14:
who
was

\n

actually a really nice guy (kinda cute) and she had a great time telling jokes
and dancing. She was having such a good time that before she knew it
column15:
it was
time to leave. Everybody shook her hand and

\n

waved goodbye as she got on the elevator.

\n

The elevator went up and opened back up at the Pearly Gates
column16:
and she found St.
Peter waiting for her. "Now it''s time to spend a day in heaven
column17:
he said. So she
spent the next 24 hours lounging around on clouds and playing the harp and
singing. She had a great time, and before she knew it, her 24 hours were up and
St. Peter came and got her and asked her to choose.

\n

The woman paused for a second and then replied, Well
column18:
I never thought I''d say
this
column19: I mean
column20: Heaven has been really great and all
column21:
but I think I had a better
time in Hell." So St. Peter escorted her to the elevator and again she went
down-down-down back to Hell.

\n

When the doors of the elevator opened
column22:
she found herself standing in a
desolate wasteland covered in garbage and filth. She saw her friends were
dressed in rags and were picking up the garbage and putting it in sacks. The
Devil came up to her and put his arm around her.

\n

"I don''t understand
column23:
stammered the woman, yesterday I was here and there was
a golf course and a country club and we ate lobster and we danced and had a
great time. Now
column24:
all there is a wasteland of garbage and all my friends look
miserable."

\n

The Devil looked at her and smiled. "Yesterday
column25: we were recruiting you
column26:
today
you''re staff."

you see that''s your problem. You
should have been taking golf lessons instead."

column1: A golfer

column8: annoyed
column9: says

column11: says the salesman. You can never lose it!" "Whattaya mean
column12: scoffs the golfer, you can never lose it? What if you hit it into the water?" "No problem
column13: says the salesman. It floats
column14: and it detects where the shore is
column15: and spins towards it." "Well
column16: what if you hit it into the woods?" "Easy
column17: says the salesman. It emits a beeping sound
column18: and you can find it with your eyes closed." "Okay

column22: you can never lose this golf ball!" The golfer buys it at once. "Just one question
column23: he says to the salesman. Where did you get it?" "I found it."

column1: ''You can''t be a real country unless you have a beer and an airline. It helps if you have some kind of a football team or some nuclear weapons
column2:
but at the very least you need a beer.'' - Frank Zappa.

''Always do sober what you said you''d do drunk. That will teach you to keep your mouth shut.'' - Ernest Hemingway.

''Always remember that I have taken more out of alcohol than alcohol has taken out of me.'' - Winston Churchill.

''He was a wise man who invented beer.'' - Plato.

''Time is never wasted when you''re wasted all the time.'' - Catherine Zondonella.

''A woman drove me to drink and I didn''t even have the decency to thank her.'' - W. C. Fields.

''Sir
column3: if you were my husband
column4:
I would poison your drink.'' - Lady Astor to Winston Churchill.
''Madam
column5:
if you were my wife I would drink it.'' - Churchill''s reply.
''Sir
column6:
you''re drunk!'' - Lady Astor to Winston Churchill.
''Yes madam
column7:
and you''re ugly. But in the morning I will be sober.'' - Churchill''s reply.

\n

''If God had intended us to drink beer
column8:
He would have given us stomachs.'' - David Daye.

\n

''When I read about the evils of drinking
column9:
I gave up reading.'' - Henny Youngman.

\n

''Beer is proof that God loves us and wants us to be happy.'' - Benjamin Franklin.

\n

''If you ever reach total enlightenment while drinking beer
column10:
I bet it makes beer shoot out your nose.'' - Jack Handy.

\n

''Without question
column11: the greatest invention in the history of mankind is beer. Oh
column12: I grant you that the wheel was also a fine invention
column13:
but the wheel does not go nearly as well with pizza.'' - Dave Barry.

''The problem with the world is that everyone is a few drinks behind.'' - Humphrey Bogart.

''Why is American beer served cold? So you can tell it from urine.'' - David Moulton.

''People who drink light beer don''t like the taste of beer
column14: they just like to pee a lot.'' - Capital Brewery
column15: Middleton
column16:
Wisconsin.

''Give me a woman who loves beer and I will conquer the world.'' - Kaiser Wilhelm.

''I would kill everyone in this room for a drop of sweet beer.'' - Homer Simpson.

''Not all chemicals are bad. Without chemicals such as hydrogen and oxygen
column17: for example
column18: there would be no way to make water
column19:
a vital ingredient in beer.'' - Unknown

''I drink to make other people interesting.'' - George Jean Nathan.

''They who drink beer will think beer.'' - Washington Irving.

''An intelligent man is sometimes forced to be drunk to spend time with his fools.'' - Ernest Hemingway in For Whom the Bell Tolls.

''You''re not drunk if you can lie on the floor without holding on.'' - Dean Martin.

''All right
column20: brain
column21: I don''t like you and you don''t like me - so let''s just do this and I''ll get back to killing you with beer.'' - Homer Simpson.

column1: A guy is stranded on a desert island
column2: all alone for ten years. One day
column3:
he
sees a speck on the horizon. He thinks to himself
column4:
"It''s not a ship." The
speck gets a little closer and he thinks
column5:
"It''s not a boat." The speck gets
even closer and he thinks
column6: "It''s not a raft." Then
column7:
out of the surf comes a
gorgeous blonde woman
column8:
wearing a wet suit and scuba gear.

\n

She comes up to the guy and says
column9:
"How long has it been since you''ve had a
cigarette?"

\n

"Ten years!"
column10:
he says.

\n

She reaches over and unzips a waterproof pocket on her left sleeve and pulls
out a pack of fresh cigarettes.

\n

He takes one
column11: lights it
column12: takes a long drag and says
column13: "Man
column14:
oh man! Is that
good!"

\n

Then she asks
column15:
"How long has it been since you''ve had a drink of whiskey?"

\n

He replies
column16:
"Ten years!"

\n

She reaches over
column17: unzips her waterproof pocket on her right sleeve
column18:
pulls out
a flask and gives it to him.

\n

He takes a long swig and says
column19: "Wow
column20:
that''s fantastic!"

\n

Then she starts unzipping this long zipper that runs down the front of her
wet suit and she says to him
column21:
"And how long has it been since you''ve had some
real fun?"

\n

And the man replies
column22:
"My God! Don''t tell me that you''ve got golf clubs in
there!"

column1: Forget about Dog Bites Man. Relegate Man Bites Dog to the back pages. Today we are dealing with Fish swallows dog
column2:
an item which reaches us by way of Moscow.

\n

The dog was swimming across the Pechora River to join its master when it vanished
column3: leaving only a ripple. The dog''s master
column4: who was fishing at the time
column5:
hauled in his net and found it contained a giant pike. He looked closely at its mouth and said to himself (probably) "Thereby hangs a tail."

\n

Yes
column6: it was Fido (or the Russian equivalent). The dog struggled out after the fish was cut open
column7: and
column8: according to Radio Moscow
column9: hurled itself at the pike
column10:
"barking excitedly."

\n

It is often difficult for fishermen to tell stories about the one that got away. In this case
column11: Radio Moscow notwithstanding
column12: will it be any easier to tell about the one that didn''t?

column1:
I was playing golf with my doctor friend one day.
He ALWAYS hit his drives right down the middle of the fairway.
My problem was that I ALWAYS hooked my ball completely off the fairway.

\n

I asked him for help
column2:
and he offered to give me a physical to see if he could determine the problem.

\n

Sure enough
column3: he said that I had three times the "normal length" of the average male
column4:
which caused an anomaly in my swing that caused me to hook.

\n

I asked him to help me
column5:
and he agreed to do surgery -- provided that I didn''t play golf for four weeks. I agreed. Golf is just that important to me.

\n

Four weeks later
column6: new body and all
column7: I teed off on the first hole and drove the ball 270 yards right down the middle. Feeling elated
column8:
I thanked the doctor.

\n

Then I asked him what had become of the "rest" of me.

\n

He just smiled
column9: teed his ball
column10:
then hit it...
and watched it duck hook two fairways away...

column1: The Cameron children are the sort of kids who really light up a room
column2:
and then
are content to leave it lit until all the electricity in the country has flowed
through our circuits and out into the night. I''m developing carpal tunnel
syndrome from the repetitive motion of turning off the lights after them
column3:
and
can''t understand how they could possibly fail to notice a blazing light bulb
column4: for crying out loud. When I walk into the house in the evenings
column5:
every single
room is as brilliantly lit as a hospital operating theater. The little wheel
that measures the electricity sluicing through my home spins inside its glass
case like a CD player
column6:
and no one can walk within 100 feet of my yard without
casting a shadow. It looks like the grand opening of a sporting goods store.
My teenagers are the worst. Not only do they require every bulb to be lit
column7:
but
they can often be found in front of the television
column8: the phone to their ears
column9:
the
stereo blaring in the background. "I''m doing homework
column10:
they''ll protest when I
ask them to choose between one of the appliances. They use this as their
universal alibi for everything. If I were to catch them in the middle of an
armed robbery, I''m sure they would claim it was for a school assignment.
I''ve tried to explain to my family that as responsible Americans, we all need
to preserve precious natural resources like the W. Bruce Cameron bank account.
I have no desire to have the nation''s next nuclear reactor named after me
column11:
I
advise them, but they don''t seem to get it. It makes me wonder whether the power
company isn''t paying them off after school.
Let''s be reasonable. The furniture hasn''t moved. There are no falling objects
in the living room. We don''t need to turn on the lights unless there is
something special we want to look at.
But we have to do our homework!" my children protest.
"Remember Abe Lincoln?" I challenge them.
"No
column12:
they respond, We don''t remember Abe Lincoln because you won''t let us
turn on the lights so we can study."
"Very funny. Abe Lincoln never had electric lights. He studied in front of a
fireplace
column13:
doing math by writing numbers on a shovel."
"You mean his teachers let him turn in homework written on a SHOVEL?" My son
laughs
column14:
delighted.
"Also
column15:
I recall from some book I read once, he held his brother up to the
ceiling to make footprints or something."
"What was that
column16:
gym class?"
"The point is
column17:
we have to reduce our use of electricity."
"Which is why your father is giving up watching sports on the television
column18:
my
wife chimes in.
I give her a stern look. Let''s stay focused on what we''re interested in
column19: which is what I''m saying
column20:
I admonish her. It is a primary tenet of good
parenting that parents should be unified when it comes to matters of my policy.
Also
column21: whenever the thermostat is set above hypothermia
column22:
we have to turn it
down
column23: she cautions. And children
column24:
you will all need to learn Braille so you''ll
be able to read in the dark. Showers will be limited to seven seconds--if you
can''t wash your hair in that time
column25:
there''s always the hose." She smiles sweetly
at me. "Oh
column26:
and I''m going to the store tomorrow--tell me how much homework you
have so I''ll know how many garden tools to pick up."
"Instead of listening to music on the stereo
column27:
we should all just sing!" my son
suggests.
"There''s no sense in using the telephone when you can shout
column28:
my
daughter affirms.
Flushing toilets more than once a month is an extravagance!" they hoot.
"Never open the refrigerator! Doing laundry is communist!"
Well
column29:
there''s no point trying to reason with them--they''re laughing too hard
to pay attention. "As soon as you''re finished I''ll begin passing out
punishments
column30:
I state menacingly.
What are you going to do
column31: make us sit in the dark?" my daughter shrieks
column32:
holding her sides.
Half an hour later
column33:
when I stroll in to check on the thermostat and turn off a
few of the lights
column34: they''re still laughing.

column1:
*** VIRUS ALERT ***

\n

If you receive an email entitled "Fighting Canaries
column2:
delete it immediately. Do not open it! It will not only erase everything on your hard drive, but it will also delete anything on disks within 20 feet of your computer.

It demagnetises the stripes on ALL of your credit cards.
It reprograms your ATM access code, screws up the tracking on your VCR and uses subspace field harmonics to scratch any CD''s you attempt to play.

It will re-calibrate your refrigerator''s coolness settings so all your ice cream melts and your milk curdles.
It will program your phone autodial to call only your mother-in-law''s number.

This virus will mix antifreeze into your fish tank.
It will drink all your beer.
It will leave dirty socks on the coffee table when you are expecting company.

Its radioactive emissions will cause your toe jam and bellybutton fuzz (be honest, you have some) to migrate behind your ears.
It will replace your shampoo with Nair and your Nair with Rogaine, all while dating your current boy/girlfriend behind your back and billing their hotel rendezvous to your Visa card.
It will cause you to run with scissors and throw things in a way that is only fun until someone loses an eye.

It will give you Dutch Elm Disease and Tinea.
It will rewrite your backup files, changing all your active verbs to passive tense and incorporating undetectable misspellings which grossly change theinterpretations of key sentences.

If the Badtimes" message is opened in a Windows95 environment
column3:
it will leave the toilet seat up and leave your hair dryer plugged in dangerously close to a full bathtub.

\n

It will not only remove the forbidden tags from your mattresses and pillows
column4:
but it will also refill your skim milk with whole milk.
It will replace all your luncheon meat with Spam.
It will molecularly rearrange your cologne or perfume
column5:
causing it to smell like dill pickles.

\n

It is insidious and subtle. It is dangerous and terrifying to behold. It is also a rather interesting shade of mauve.

\n

These are just a few signs of infection...

column1: In a crowded city at a crowded bus stop
column2: a beautiful blonde was waiting for the bus. She was decked out in a tight leather mini skirt with matching tight leather boots and jacket. As the bus rolled up and it became her turn to get on
column3:
she became aware that her skirt was too tight to allow her leg to come up to the height of the first step on the bus.
Slightly embarrassed and with a quick smile to the bus driver she reached behind her and unzipped her skirt a little thinking that this would give her enough slack to raise her leg. Again she tried to make the step onto the bus only to discover she still couldn''t! So
column4: a little more embarrassed she once again reached behind her and unzipped her skirt a little more and for a second time attempted the step and once again
column5: much to her chagrin she could not raise her leg because of the tight skirt. So
column6:
with a coy little smile to the driver she again unzipped the offending skirt to give a little more slack and again was unable to make the step.

\n

About this time the big Texan that was behind her in the line picked her up easily from the waist and placed her lightly on the step of the bus Well
column7:
she went ballistic and turned on the would-be hero screeching at him "How dare you touch my body!! I don''t even know who you are!"

\n

At this the Texan drawled "Well ma''am normally I would agree with you but after you unzipped my fly three times
column8: I kinda figured that we was friends."

column1: One day the big animals and the little animals decided to have a football game. As the first half went along
column2:
the big animals were scoring at will. Every time they got the ball they would run it in for a touchdown.

Then came the second half...

First play: The elephant runs the ball up the middle. WAP!! Tackled for a five yard loss.

The little animals go back to the huddle cheering and congratulating each other.

"Who made that tackle?" asked the ant.

"I did
column3:
said the centipede.

\n

Second play: The rhinoceros runs the ball up the middle. WHOMP!! Tackled for another five yard loss.

\n

Back in the huddle the flea asked, Who made that great stop?" "I did
column4:
said the centipede.

Third play: The gorilla tries an end sweep, led by the hippo throwing the lead blocks. SMACK!! Centipede tackles him for a ten yard loss.

Back in the huddle, the gnat asked the centipede, Where were you in the first half?"

The centipede replied
column5: "Puttin'' on my shoes!"

column1: As a young man
column2:
Norton was an exceptional golfer. At the age of
26
column3: however
column4: he decided to become a priest
column5:
and joined a rather
peculiar Order. He took the usual vows of poverty
column6: chastity
column7:
but
his Order also required that he quit golf and never play again.
This was particularly difficult for Norton
column8:
but he agreed and
was finally ordained a priest.

\n

One Sunday morning
column9:
the Reverend Father Norton woke up and
realizing it was an exceptionally beautiful and sunny early
spring day
column10:
decided he just had to play golf.

\n

So... he told the Associate Pastor that he was feeling sick and
convinced him to say Mass for him that day. As soon as the
Associate Pastor left the room
column11:
Father Norton headed out of town
to a golf course about forty miles away. This way he knew he
wouldn''t accidentally meet anyone he knew from his parish.

\n

Setting up on the first tee
column12: he was alone. After all
column13:
it was
Sunday morning and everyone else was in church! At about this
time
column14:
Saint Peter leaned over to the Lord while looking down
from the heavens and exclaimed
column15:
"You''re not going to let him get
away with this
column16:
are you?"

\n

The Lord sighed
column17: and said
column18: "No
column19:
I guess not." Just then Father
Norton hit the ball and it shot straight towards the pin
column20: dropping just short of it
column21:
rolled up and fell into the hole. It
WAS A 420 YARD HOLE IN ONE! St. Peter was astonished. He looked
at the Lord and asked
column22:
"Why did you let him do that?" The Lord
smiled and replied
column23: "Who is he going to tell?"

column1: A husband and wife are traveling by car from Atlanta to New York. After almost twenty-four hours on the road
column2: they''re too tired to continue
column3: and they decide to stop for a rest. They stop at a nice hotel and take a room
column4:
but they only plan to sleep for four hours and then get back on the road.

\n

When they check out four hours later
column5: the desk clerk hands them a bill for $350. The man explodes and demands to know why the charge is so high. He tells the clerk although it''s a nice hotel
column6: the rooms certainly aren''t worth $350. When the clerk tells him $350 is the standard rate
column7:
the man insists on speaking to the manager.

\n

The manager listens to the man and then explains the hotel has an Olympic-sized pool and a huge conference center that were available for the husband and wife to use. He also explains they could have taken in one of the shows for which the hotel is famous.

\n

"The best entertainers from New York
column8: Hollywood and Las Vegas perform here
column9:
explains the manager.

No matter what facility the manager mentions, the man replies, But we didn''t use it!"

The manager is unmoved and eventually the man gives up and agrees to pay. He writes a check and gives it to the manager. The manager is surprised when he looks at the check.

"But sir
column10:
he says, this check is only made out for $100."

\n

"That''s right
column11:
says the man. I charged you $250 for kissing my wife."

\n

"But I didn''t!" exclaims the manager.

\n

"Well
column12: the man replies, she was here
column13: and you could have."

column1:
An old couple in Santo Domingo was puzzled when the coffin
of their dead relative arrived from the USA. The corpse was
so tightly squeezed inside the coffin that her face was
practically touching the glass cover. When they opened the
coffin
column2: they found a letter pinned to her chest
column3:
which
read:

Dearest Papi & Mami:

I am sending you Tia Juana''s remains for the funeral in the
Santo Domingo Cemetery.

Sorry I couldn''t come along as the expenses were too high.
You will find inside the coffin
column4: under Tia''s body
column5:
12 cans
of Bumble Bee Tuna
column6:
12 bottles of Paul Mitchell Shampoo and
12 bottles Paul Mitchell Conditioner
column7:
12 Vaseline Intensive
Care Skin Lotion
column8:
12 Colgate Toothpaste and 12 cans of
Spam. Just divide it among the family.

\n

On Tia''s feet is a brand-new pair of Reeboks (size 8) for
Joseito. There are four pairs of Reeboks under her head for
Antonio''s sons. Tia is wearing six Ralph Lauren T-shirts -
one is for Roberto and the rest are for his sons.

\n

Tia is also wearing one dozen Wonder Bras (my favorite)
column9:
just divide it among the ladies. The 2 dozen Victoria''s
Secret panties that she is wearing should be distributed
among my nieces and cousins. Tia is also wearing eight
Docker pants
column10:
please keep one for yourself and the rest are
for the boys.

\n

The Swiss watch you asked for is on Tia Juana''s left wrist
and she is also wearing what you asked for Mami (earrings
column11:
ring and necklace) just please get them before anyone
arrives to view the body. Also
column12:
the six pairs of Chanel
stockings that she is wearing must be divided among the
teen-age girls there. I hope the colors are to their
liking.

\n

Your loving daughter

column1:
Dear Technical Support:

\n

I''m currently running the latest version of GirlFriend and I''ve
been having some problems lately. I''ve been running the same
version of DrinkingBuddies 1.0 forever as my primary
application
column2:
and all the GirlFriend releases I''ve tried have
always conflicted with it. I hear that DrinkingBuddies won''t
crash if GirlFriend is run in background mode and the sound is
turned off. But I''m embarrassed to say I can''t find the switch
to turn the sound off. I just run them separately
column3:
and it works
okay.

\n

Girlfriend also seems to have a problem co-existing with my Golf
program
column4:
often trying to abort Golf with some sort of timing
incompatibility.

\n

I probably should have stayed with GirlFriend 1.0
column5:
but I thought
I might see better performance from GirlFriend 2.0. After months
of conflicts and other problems
column6:
I consulted a friend who has
had experience with GirlFriend 2.0. He said I probably didn''t
have enough cache to run GirlFriend 2.0
column7:
and eventually it would
require a Token Ring to run properly. He was right - as soon as
I purged my cache
column8:
it uninstalled itself.

\n

Shortly after that
column9:
I installed GirlFriend 3.0 beta. All the
bugs were supposed to be gone
column10: but the first time I used it
column11:
it
gave me a virus anyway. I had to clean out my whole system and
shut down for a while. I very cautiously upgraded to GirlFriend
4.0. This time I used a SCSI probe first and also installed a
virus protection program. It worked okay for a while until I
discovered that GirlFriend 1.0 was still in my system. I tried
running GirlFriend 1.0 again with GirlFriend 4.0 still
installed
column12:
but GirlFriend 4.0 has a feature I didn''t know about
that automatically senses the presence of any other version of
GirlFriend and communicates with it in some way
column13:
which results
in the immediate removal of both versions.

\n

The version I have now works pretty well
column14:
but there are still
some problems. Like all versions of GirlFriend
column15:
it is written in
some obscure language I can''t understand
column16:
much less reprogram.
Frankly I think there is too much attention paid to the look and
feel rather than the desired functionality. Also
column17:
to get the
best connections with your hardware
column18:
you usually have to use
gold-plated contacts. And I''ve never liked how GirlFriend is
totally "object-oriented." A year ago
column19:
a friend of mine upgraded
his version of GirlFriend to GirlFriendPlus 1.0
column20:
which is a
Terminate and Stay Resident version of GirlFriend. He discovered
that GirlFriendPlus 1.0 expires within a year if you don''t
upgrade to Fiancee 1.0. So he did
column21: but soon after that
column22:
he had
to upgrade to Wife 1.0
column23:
which he describes as a huge resource
hog. It has taken up all his space
column24:
so he can''t load anything
else. One of the primary reasons he decided to go with Wife 1.0
was because it came bundled with FreeSexPlus. Well
column25:
it turns out
the resource allocation module of Wife 1.0 sometimes prohibits
access to FreeSexPlus
column26:
particularly the new Plug-Ins he wanted
to try. On top of that
column27:
Wife 1.0 must be running on a well
warmed-up system before he can do anything. Although he did not
ask for it
column28:
Wife 1.0 came with MotherInLaw which has an
automatic pop-up feature he can''t turn off.

\n

I told him to try installing Mistress 1.0
column29:
but he said he heard
if you try to run it without first uninstalling Wife 1.0
column30:
Wife
1.0 will delete MSMoney files before doing the uninstall itself.
Then Mistress 1.0 won''t install anyway because of insufficient
resources. Any Ideas???

There is a war going on and the Americans control one side of a
river and the Japanese control the other side. There is an
American soldier patrolling one side of the river and a Japanese
on the other. Every day at the same time the American and the
Japanese meet at the same spot
column2:
and the two are always trying to
talk but they can''t understand what each other are saying.

\n

So one day the Japanese soldier makes a motion that resembled
the sun rising over a mountain. So the American says
column3:
"Ya the
sun rising over the mountain
column4:
but I don''t understand what you
are talking about." So the two keep walking. The next day the
Japanese makes a swimming motion to the American
column5:
so the
American says
column6:
"Ya swimming but I still don''t understand what
you are talking about." So they keep on walking.

\n

The next day they meet and the Japanese makes motions like a
river
column7: and the American says
column8:
"Ya the river but I still don''t
know what you are talking about." So the two keep walking. The
next day the Japanese puts two of his fingers in a circle made
from his fingers. So the American says
column9:

still have no clue what you are talking about." So they keep
walking.

\n

The next day they meet and the Japanese makes a motion like his
eyes are popping out. So the American goes

General. "General
column11: General

column1: BECAUSE I''M A GUY   Because I''m a guy
column2: I must hold the television remote control in my hand while I watch TV. If the thing has been misplaced
column3: I''ll miss a whole show looking for it
column4:
though one time I was able to survive by holding a calculator.
Because I''m a guy
column5: when I lock my keys in the car I will fiddle with a wire clothes hanger and ignore your suggestions that we call a road service until long after hypothermia has set in. Oh
column6: and when the car isn''t running very well
column7: I will pop the hood and stare at the engine as if I know what I''m looking at. If another guy shows up
column8: one of us will say to the other
column9: "I used to be able to fix these things
column10: but now with all these computers and everything
column11:
I wouldn''t know where to start." We will then drink beer.

\n

Because I''m a guy
column12: when I catch a cold I need someone to bring me soup and take care of me while I lie in bed and moan. You never get as sick as I do
column13:
so for you this isn''t an issue.

\n

Because I''m a guy
column14: I can be relied upon to purchase basic groceries at the store
column15: like milk or bread. I cannot be expected to find exotic items like "cumin" or "tofu." For all I know these are the same thing. And never
column16: under any circumstances
column17:
expect me to pick up anything for which "feminine hygiene product" is a euphemism.

\n

Because I''m a guy
column18:
when one of our appliances stops working I will insist on taking it apart -- despite evidence that this will just cost me twice as much once the repair person gets here and has to put it back together.

\n

Because I''m a guy
column19: I don''t think we''re all that lost
column20: and no
column21:
I don''t think we should stop and ask someone. Why would you listen to a complete stranger -- how the heck could HE know where we''re going?

\n

Because I''m a guy
column22: there is no need to ask me what I''m thinking about. The answer is always either sex or football
column23: though I have to make up something else when you ask
column24:
so don''t.

\n

Because I''m a guy
column25: I do not want to visit your mother
column26: or have your mother come visit us
column27: or talk to her when she calls
column28: or think about her any more than I have to. Whatever you got her for Mother''s Day is okay
column29: I don''t need to see it. Did you remember to pick up something for my mom
column30:
too?

\n

Because I''m a guy
column31: I am capable of announcing
column32: "one more beer and I really have to go
column33:
and mean it every single time I say it, even when it gets to the point that the one bar closes and my buddies and I have to go hunt down another. I will find it increasingly hilarious to have my pals call you to tell you I''ll be home soon, and no, I don''t understand why you threw all my clothes into the front yard. What''s the connection?

Because I''m a guy, you don''t have to ask me if I liked the movie. Chances are, if you''re crying at the end of it, I didn''t.

Because I''m a guy, yes, I have to turn up the radio when Bruce Springsteen or The Doors comes on, and then, yes, I have to tell you every single time about how Bruce had his picture on the cover of Time and Newsweek the same day, or how Jim Morrison is buried in Paris and everyone visits his grave. Please do not behave as if you do not find this fascinating.

Because I''m a guy, I think what you''re wearing is fine. I thought what you were wearing five minutes ago was fine, too. Either pair of shoes is fine. With the belt or without it looks fine. Your hair is fine. You look fine. Can we just go now?

Because I''m a guy and this is, after all, the ''90s, I will share equally in the housework. You do the laundry, the cooking, the cleaning and the dishes. I''ll do the rest. Our story begins at the Olympics, specifically the wrestling event. It is narrowed down to the Russian or the American for the gold medal. Before the final match, the American wrestler''s trainer came to him and said, Now don''t forget all the research we''ve done on this Russian. He''s never lost a match because of this "pretzel" hold he has. Whatever you do
column34: don''t let him get you in this hold! If he does
column35:
you''re finished!"

\n

The wrestler nodded in agreement.

\n

Now
column36: to the match: The American and the Russian circled each other several times looking for an opening. All of a sudden the Russian lunged forward
column37: grabbing the American and wrapping him up in the dreaded pretzel hold! A sigh of disappointment went up from the crowd
column38: and the trainer buried his face in his hands for he knew all was lost. He couldn''t watch the ending. Suddenly there was a scream
column39: a cheep from the crowd
column40: and the trainer raised his eye just in time to see the Russian flying up in the air. The Russian''s back hit the mat with a thud
column41: and the American weakly collapsed on top of him
column42:
getting the pin and winning the match. The trainer was astounded!

\n

When he finally got the American wrestler alone
column43: he asks
column44:
"How did you ever get out of that hold? No one has ever done it before!"

\n

The wrestler answered
column45: "Well
column46: I was ready to give up when he got me in that hold
column47: but at the last moment
column48: I opened my eyes and saw this pair of balls right in front of my face. I thought I had nothing to lose
column49: so with my last ounce of strength I stretched out my neck and bit those babies just as hard as I could. "You''d be amazed how strong you get when you bite your own balls!"

column1: While visiting England recently
column2:
George W. Bush was invited to have tea with the Queen.

\n

Given his recent political problems
column3:
he decides to take advantage of her years of leadership experience and asks her for her advice. She responds that she surrounds herself with the most intelligent people she can find and lets them do their jobs.

\n

Intrigued with this novel theory
column4:
Bush asks her how she is able to tell if the people are intelligent.

\n

"I do so by asking them a test question" responds the Queen. "Allow me to demonstrate."

\n

The Queen then dials 10 Downing Street and asks to speak to Tony Blair. "Mr. Prime Minister
column5:
please answer a hypothetical question for me."

\n

"I''ll do my best
column6:
Your Majesty" responds Blair.

\n

"Your mother has a child and your father has a child" says the Queen. "The child is not your brother or your sister. Who is the child?"

\n

Tony Blair hesitates momentarily and then confidently replies
column7: "Well
column8: Your Majesty
column9:
I guess it would have to be me."

"Correct" says the Queen. "Thank you and good day to you Sir."

The Queen hangs up and says "Did you hear that Mr. Bush? See how clever he is."

Impressed
column10:
Bush replies "I certainly did. I''ll definitely be using that one when I conduct my next Cabinet shuffle back in the US."

\n

Upon returning to Washington
column11: Bush decides he''d better put some of his senior Cabinet Members to the test. He summons Dick Cheney to his office and says
column12: "Dick
column13:
I wonder if you could answer a question for me?"

\n

"Why of course Sir" Cheney responds unenthusiastically
column14:
annoyed that the President was again seeking his input on something.

\n

"Well
column15: uh
column16:
let''s say your mother has a child and your father too has a child. This child is not your brother and also is not your sister. Who is it?"

\n

Somewhat surprised at this odd question
column17:
Cheney hems and haws and finally asks if he can have some time to think about it.

\n

"Certainly" responds Bush.

\n

Cheney immediately calls a meeting of other senior Republicans and they puzzle over the question for several hours. Totally baffled
column18: they decide to conduct some research and contact a loyal Washington consulting firm. A budget of $10 million is provided and intensive research is carried out over the next two weeks. Unfortunately
column19:
the consultants are unable to come up with an answer.

\n

Desperate to prove that he is smarter than George
column20:
Cheney decides to take a chance and calls Al Gore.

\n

"I realize you are just an Tennessee redneck and are not all that wise in the ways of the world
column21:
but maybe you can help me out with a problem I have.

\n

Gore is naturally skeptical about Republican promises
column22:
but in the spirit of political co-operation he agrees to do what he can to help out.

\n

"O.K.
column23:
here goes" says Cheney. "Your mother has a child and your father has a child. The child is not your brother or your sister. Who is the child?"

\n

Without hesitating
column24: Gore responds "It would be me
column25:
of course."

\n

Impressed at the his quick response
column26:
Cheney quickly brushes off Gore and rushes to the President''s office (where he is watching football and eating snack foods under the careful observation of the Secret Service on the lookout for choking).

\n

" I know the answer to your question
column27:
you Idiot!! I know who the child is!!"

\n

Bush
column28: who was privately becoming a bit concerned at the delay in hearing back from Cheney
column29:
is delighted (when he finally remembers what it was that he asked). "Who is it Dick?" he asks.

\n

With obvious pride
column30: Cheney replies "It''s Al Gore
column31:
George - its Al Gore!!"

\n

Stunned
column32: Bush shouts in disgust
column33: "Wrong you idiot - it''s Tony Blair!!"

What does this golf ball do? Frank asked the manager of the
golf shop. "This golf ball magnetically attracts to all sorts of
holes. It depends on what direction you hit the ball in. If it
goes straight towards the hole
column2:
it will go into the hole" the
manager replied. "I''ll buy it." Frank bought this rather strange
golf ball and walked out to the golf course
column3:
where his friend
Bill
column4:
was waiting for him.

\n

The first hole was a Par 3
column5:
so Frank had a good chance of
getting a hole-in-one on this hole. After Bill had played his
first shot
column6:
Frank stuck the tee into the ground and placed his
magnetic golf ball on top of it. When he was set
column7:
Frank hit the
ball straight towards the hole and got a hole-in-one. "You can''t
ask for a better start than that Frank"
column8:
said Bill. Frank smiled.

\n

For the next sixteen holes
column9:
Frank''s weird golf ball found holes
to go into after every shot. However
column10:
most of these holes that
the ball went into were either a bunker or the hole itself.
There was one occasion though
column11:
when the ball went into one of
the pockets in Bill''s pants
column12:
but this doesn''t compare with what
happened on the eighteenth hole.

\n

Bill had already played his first shot on the eighteenth
column13:
and
Frank was about to play his. The eighteenth hole had a large
hill in which the ball had to be hit over. The hole and pin
could not be seen from where Frank and Bill were.

\n

Since this hole is a Par 3
column14:
Frank could get another hole-in-one.
When Frank was set he hit the ball
column15:
and to his disappointment he
hooked it to the left. A few seconds later
column16:
a loud noise could
be heard "Aaaaaaaargh!!!!" Frank and Bill had no idea where the
noise came from
column17:
so they both walked over the hill to look for
their balls.

\n

Bill found his ball straight away
column18:
but Frank was having great
difficulty in finding his ball. Frank had spent about twenty
minutes trying to find his ball
column19:
when he decided to give up and
use another ball. "I''ll use another ball for my second shot
Bill
column20:
but first I need to go to the toilet". Frank walked over
to the public toilets
column21:
which was about twenty meters to the left
of the eighteenth green.

\n

When Frank walked into the public toilets he heard a voice
column22:
"Is
there anyone there?" "Yes there is
column23:
replied Frank, as he walked
towards the cubicle at the far end. When he got to the cubicle
door, which was open, Frank asked the man, What do you want?"
"I need a doctor
column24:
came the reply. Why do you need a doctor?"
Frank asked curiously. After Frank asked this question
column25:
the man
in the cubicle did something strange. He stood up
column26:
turned around
and flashed his naked backside at Frank
column27:
who suddenly became
worried
column28:
"Holy shit!!!!"

\n

"What is it?" said the man in the cubicle. "You wouldn''t believe
what''s stuck up there!!" Frank said. "What is?" "My fucking golf
ball
column29: that''s what!!!!"

A male and female whale were swimming off the coast of Japan when they
noticed a whaling ship. The male whale recognized it as the same ship that had
harpooned his father many years earlier. He said to the female whale
column2:
"Let''s
both swim under the ship and blowout of our air holes at the same time and it
should cause the ship to turn over and sink". They tried it and sure enough the
ship turned over and quickly sank. Soon however
column3:
the whales realized the sailors
had jumped overboard and were swimming to the safety of shore.

\n

The male was enraged that they were going to get away and told the female
column4:
"Let''s swim after them and gobble them up before they reach the shore. At this
point
column5:
he realized the female was becoming reluctant to follow him.

\n

"Look"
column6: she said
column7: "I went along with the blow job
column8:
but I absolutely refuse to
swallow the seamen".

\n

NOTE: The average blue whale produces over 400 gallons of sperm when it
ejaculates
column9:
but only 10% of that actually makes it into his mate. So.... 360
gallons are spilled into the ocean every time one unloads
column10:
and you wonder why
the ocean is so salty......

column1: After Christmas break

We always spent Christmas with Grandpa and Grandma. They used to live here in a big brick house
column3:

\n

They go to a big building they call a wrecked hall. But if it was wrecked
column4: it is fixed now. They play games there and do exercises

\n

As you come into the park

\n

My Grandma said Grandpa worked hard all his life and earned his retardment. I wish they would move back home
column8: but I guess the man in the doll house won''t let them out.

and
without hesitating he shoved the Miami Dolphins fan off the
cliff.

column1: Last year
column2:
my friend upgraded his GirlFriend 3.1 to GirlFriend Plus 1.0 (marketing name: Fiance 1.0). Recently he upgraded Fiance 1.0 to Wife 1.0 and it''s a memory hogger: has taken up all his space.

\n

Wife 1.0 must be running before he can do anything and seems to conflict/interfere with other tasks running such as hockey 2.1
column3: squash 3.01 and boys out 1.2. Although he didn''t ask for them
column4:
Wife 1.0 came with auto-installed Plug-Ins such as Mother In Law and Brother In Law.

\n

Some features I''d like to see in the upcoming GirlFriend 4.0...
- A "Don''t remind me again" button
- Minimize button
- Shutdown feature
- An install shield feature so that Girlfriend 4.0 can be completely uninstalled if so desired (so you don''t lose cache and other objects)
- "Abort" button (O.K. that one''s pretty bad - but had to say it)

\n

I tried running Girlfriend 2.0 with Girlfriend 1.0 still installed
column5: they tried using the same I/O port and conflicted. Then I tried to uninstall  Girlfriend 1.0 but it didn''t have an uninstall program. I tried to uninstall it by hand
column6:
but it put files in my system directory. Another thing that sucks--in all versions of Girlfriend that I''ve used is that it is totally "object orientated" and only supports hardware with gold plated contacts.

\n

***** BUG WARNING ********

\n

Wife 1.0 has an undocumented bug. If you try to install Mistress 1.1 before uninstalling Wife 1.0
column7: Wife 1.0 will delete MSMoney files before doing the uninstall itself. Then Mistress 1.1 will refuse to install

column9: when activated
column10: consumes all available resources and brings your system to it''s knees. The funny thing is

column12: Wife 1.0 will eventually detect it and begin the process described above.

column1:
You walk into a room and notice that a picture is hanging crooked. You...
Straighten it. Ignore it. Buy a CAD system and spend the next six months designing a solar- powered
column2:
self-adjusting picture frame while often stating aloud your belief that the inventor of the nail was a total moron.

The correct answer is "3" but partial credit can be given to anybody who writes "It depends" in the margin of the test or simply blames the whole stupid thing on "Marketing."

SOCIAL SKILLS

Engineers have different objectives when it comes to social interaction. "Normal" people expect to accomplish several unrealistic things from social interaction: Stimulating and thought-provoking conversation Important social contacts A feeling of connectedness with other humans In contrast to "normal" people
column3:
engineers have rational objectives for social interactions: Get it over with as soon as possible Avoid getting invited to something unpleasant Demonstrate mental superiority and mastery of all subjects.

\n

FASCINATION WITH GADGETS

\n

To the engineer
column4: all matter in the universe can be placed into one of two categories: (1) things that need to be fixed
column5: and (2) things that will need to be fixed after you''ve had a few minutes to play with them. Engineers like to solve problems. If there are no problems handily available
column6: they will create their own problems. Normal people don''t understand this concept; they believe that if it ain''t broke
column7: don''t fix it. Engineers believe that if it ain''t broke
column8: it doesn''t have enough features yet. No engineer looks at a television remote control without wondering what it would take to turn it into a stun gun. No engineer can take a shower without wondering if some sort of Teflon coating would make showering unnecessary. To the engineer
column9:
the world is a toy box full of sub-optimized and feature-poor toys.

\n

FASHION AND APPEARANCE

\n

Clothes are the lowest priority for an engineer
column10: assuming the basic thresholds for temperature and decency have been satisfied. If no appendages are freezing or sticking together
column11: and if no genitalia or mammary glands are swinging around in plain view
column12:
then the objective of clothing has been met. Anything else is a waste.

DATING AND SOCIAL LIFE

Dating is never easy for engineers. A normal person will employ various indirect and duplicitous methods to create a false impression of attractiveness. Engineers are incapable of placing appearance above function.

Fortunately
column13: engineers have an ace in the hole. They are widely recognized as superior marriage material: intelligent
column14: dependable
column15: employed
column16: honest
column17: and handy around the house. While it''s true that many normal people would prefer not to date an engineer
column18: most normal people harbor an intense desire to mate with them
column19:
thus producing engineer like children who will have high-paying jobs long before losing their virginity.

\n

Male engineers reach their peak of sexual attractiveness later than normal men
column20:
becoming irresistible erotic dynamos in their mid thirties to late forties. Just look at these examples of sexually irresistible men in technical professions:

Bill Gates MacGyver Etcetera

Female engineers become irresistible at the age of consent and remain that way until about thirty minutes after their clinical death. Longer if it''s a warm day.

HONESTY

Engineers are always honest in matters of technology and human relationships. That''s why it''s a good idea to keep engineers away from customers
column21: romantic interests
column22:
and other people who can''t handle the truth.

Engineers sometimes bend the truth to avoid work. They say things that sound like lies but technically are not because nobody could be expected to believe them. The

complete list of engineer lies is listed below.

"I won''t change anything without asking you first." "I''ll return your hard-to-find cable tomorrow." "I have to have new equipment to do my job." "I''m not jealous of your new computer."

FRUGALITY

Engineers are notoriously frugal. This is not because of cheapness or mean spirit; it is simply because every spending situation is simply a problem in optimization
column23: that is
column24:
"How can I escape this situation while retaining the greatest amount of cash?"

POWERS OF CONCENTRATION

If there is one trait that best defines an engineer it is the ability to concentrate on one subject to the complete exclusion of everything else in the environment. This sometimes causes engineers to be pronounced dead prematurely. Some funeral homes in high-tech areas have started checking resumes before processing the bodies. Anybody with a degree in electrical engineering or experience in computer programming is propped up in the lounge for a few days just to see if he or she snaps out of it.

RISK

Engineers hate risk. They try to eliminate it whenever they can. This is understandable
column25:
given that when an engineer makes one little mistake the media will treat it like it''s a big deal or something.

EXAMPLES OF BAD PRESS FOR ENGINEERS Hindenberg Space Shuttle Challenger SPANet(tm) Hubble space telescope Apollo 13 Titanic Ford Pinto Corvair

The risk/reward calculation for engineers looks something like this:

RISK: Public humiliation and the death of thousands of innocent people. REWARD: A certificate of appreciation in a handsome plastic frame.

Being practical people
column26:
engineers evaluate this balance of risks and rewards and decide that risk is not a good thing. The best way to avoid risk is by advising that any activity is technically impossible for reasons that are far too complicated to explain.

\n

If that approach is not sufficient to halt project
column27:
then the engineer will fall back to a second line of defense: "It''s technically possible but it will cost too much."

\n

EGO

\n

Ego-wise
column28:
two things are important to engineers: How smart they are. How many cool devices they own. The fastest way to get an engineer to solve a problem is to declare that the problem is unsolvable. No engineer can walk away from an unsolvable problem until it''s solved. No illness or distraction is sufficient to get the engineer off the case. These types of challenges quickly become personal --a battle between the engineer and the laws of nature.

\n

Engineers will go without food and hygiene for days to solve a problem. (Other times just because they forgot.) And when they succeed in solving the problem they will experience an ego rush that is better than sex -- and I''m including the kind of sex where other people are involved.

\n

Nothing is more threatening to the engineer than the suggestion that somebody has more technical skill. Normal people sometimes use that knowledge as a lever to extract more work from the engineer. When an engineer says that something can''t be done (a code phrase that means it''s not fun to do)
column29:
some clever normal people have learned to glance at the engineer with a look of compassion and pity and say something along these lines: "I''ll ask Bob to figure it out. He knows how to solve difficult technical problems."

\n

At that point it is a good idea for the normal person to not stand between the engineer and the problem. The engineer will set upon the problem like a starved Chihuahua on a pork chop.

THE GERMAN PRESSED HER FOREARM AND THE BEEP STOPPED.

THE OTHERS LOOKED AT HER QUESTIONINGLY.

"THAT WAS MY PAGER
column3:
SHE SAID. I HAVE A MICROCHIP UNDER THE SKIN OF MY ARM."

\n

A FEW MINUTES LATER
column4:
A PHONE RANG.

\n

THE JAPANESE WOMAN LIFTED HER PALM TO HER EAR. WHEN SHE FINISHED
column5: SHE EXPLAINED
column6:
"THAT WAS MY MOBILE PHONE. I HAVE A MICROCHIP IN MY HAND."

\n

THE HILLBILLY WOMAN FELT DECIDEDLY LOW TECH. NOT TO BE OUTDONE
column7:
SHE DECIDED SHE HAD TO DO SOMETHING JUST AS IMPRESSIVE.

SHE STEPPED OUT OF THE SAUNA AND WENT TO THE BATHROOM. SHE RETURNED WITH A PIECE OF TOILET PAPER HANGING FROM HER BEHIND.

THE OTHERS RAISED THEIR EYEBROWS AND STARED AT HER.

THE HILLBILLY WOMAN FINALLY SAID
column8: "WELL
column9: WILL YOU LOOK AT THAT
column10:
I''M GETTIN'' A FAX!

\n

Submitted by NCrespi
Edited by Curtis and Yisman

column1: A boy in the sixth grade comes home after school one day. His mother notices that he''s got a big smile on his face. She asks
column2: "Did anything special happen at school today?""Yes
column3: Mom. I had sex with my English teacher!" The mother is stunned."You''re going to talk about this with your father when he gets home."Well
column4: when dad comes home and hears the news he is pleased as punch. Beaming with pride
column5: he walks over to his son and says
column6: "Son
column7: I hear you had sex with your English teacher.""That''s right
column8: Dad.""Well
column9: you became a man today - this is cause for celebration. Let''s head out for some ice cream
column10: and then I''ll buy that new bike you''ve been asking for.""That sounds great
column11: Dad
column12: but I can I have a football instead? My ass is killing me."

column1: A textbook nerd is at the beach one day
column2: baring his chest and showing off his pale
column3: shrunken chest
column4: and of course all the girls are laughing at him and drooling over the weight-lifting hunks. So in desperation the kid goes to the lifeguard and asks
column5:
"How can I do something to get these girls interested in me? What can I do to show off?"

\n

The lifeguard takes pity on this poor guy
column6: with his puny muscles and baggy trunks and lanky hair
column7: and finally he says
column8: "Tell you what - why don�酶惟t you take a potato and stick it down your swim trunks. That way the girls will think you�酶惟ve got something really big and hard down there
column9:
and they�酶惟ll want you."

\n

So the nerd decides to give it a try. He struts around the beach with a potato in his shorts
column10: and all the girls give him weird
column11: disgusting looks and tell him to get the hell out of there. The nerd can�酶惟t understand what�酶惟s going on
column12: so he goes back to the lifeguard and asks
column13:
"What am I doing wrong? You said they�酶惟d like me if I put a potato in my shorts!"

\n

Without even batting an eye
column14: the lifeguard says
column15: "You gotta put the potato in the FRONT
column16: kid!"

column1: It had promised to be a sensational divorce case
column2: with the wife accused of incredible escapades. Testifying before her own attorney
column3: she projected an image of sweet innocence
column4: told a tale of wifely fidelity and sacrifice
column5:
and was quite believable.

\n

When it was time for cross-examination though
column6: the husband''s lawyer arose and said
column7: "Isn''t it true that on the night of June 12
column8: in a driving rainstorm
column9:
you had sexual intercourse with a certain circus midget on the handle bars of a careening motorcycle as it raced across a private golf course reaching speeds in excess of seventy-five miles per hour?"

\n

She turned pale but retained her remarkable self-control and composure.

\n

Her voice was almost serene in its innocence as she asked
column10: "What was that date again ?"

column1: Researchers released a list of foods and activities to help  combat osteoporosis
column2: the dread disorder that leaches calcium  from the bones as people age.The distinguished lead scientist mounts the podium to make  his announcement and gives the highlights of the list. To no  one''s surprise
column3: broccoli and cauliflower are there
column4: and the  researchers also encourage regular exercise
column5: such as walking
column6: running
column7: cycling or swimming to prevent calcium loss from the  bones.But
column8: one reporter
column9: reading ahead
column10: shouts from the front row
column11: "You''ve got kissing on the list as a way to prevent  osteoporosis! There isn''t any calcium in a kiss!"The scientist replied calmly
column12: "In a good kiss
column13: there''s enough calcium to make a bone about 6 inches long."

column1: A guy is golfing with his pretty wife
column2:
who is a very poor golfer. On the first hole she sends the ball smashing through the window of a nearby house.

\n

The couple goes to the house to investigate the damage and finds the door open. They go inside and found a man sitting on a couch next to the broken window. There is also a broken oil-lamp.

\n

The husband asks: "Did we break that too?"
"Yes"
column3:
replies the man.

\n

"Sorry. Do you live here?" the husband asks.

\n

"No
column4: actually
column5: I''m a genie." The man states. "I was sleeping in that lamp when your golf ball smashed it. Now
column6: I''m supposed to give you three wishes
column7: but I''m keeping one for myself since you smashed my lamp. OK
column8:
what''ll they be?"

\n

The husband thinks a moment: "First
column9:
make my wife a better golfer."
"Poof! She''s a better golfer"
column10:
the genie announces.

\n

"Second
column11:
I want a million bucks a week for life."
"Poof! you get a million bucks a week"
column12:
the genie announces.

\n

"Good. OK
column13:
what do you want?" asks the husband.
"For my wish. I want to have my way with your pretty wife
column14:

\n

Hmmm"
column15: the husband hesitated

and our golf games will be much more interesting. Go ahead."

\n

So the genie and the wife retire the bedroom. After several steamy hours the "genie" says to the wife: "How long have you known your husband?"
"Ten years
